utterances: Well, I mean, when I was younger, I loved all kinds of poets, but a performance-style of poetry, it was a combination of Gregory Corso, Vachel Lindsay, Walt Whitman, very - Oscar Brown, Jr. I got my style from a lot of different people, even my style of reading, even Johnny Carson inspired me.
Johnny Carson?
Just a very frontal style, to get up in front of the people and read, improvise a little, spar.
So my style of performance poetry came from the beatniks, Allen Ginsberg.
Yes, Ferlinghetti.
Yeah, but really that kind of frontal energy, you know, I gleaned from a lot of different factors, not just poetry.
Right, right.
It's so cool because when I smile, right now, you know, I'm filled with anxious apprehension.
It's - the loneliness is emptiness.
It's just a void.
It's so cool to talk to you.
Well, thanks a lot.
Thanks for the call, Jersey Boy.
All right.
You take care now, all right?
Bye-bye.
Okay, bye-bye.

I could just sit and watch him type...

I wanted to share a little story with you.
We've adapted the song ""Gloria"" to a local legend here in town, and the reason why we had to adopt it is we were having the Christmas boat parade and our friend Gloria was dressed up as Mrs. Claus.
And in the local canteen where we have some adult beverages, we would always play her song.
We'd have a great time singing ""Gloria"" out loud, the whole bar would.

And, anyways, back to the parade, little kids were yelling, Mrs. Claus, Mrs. Claus, and she wasn't paying them any attention because she didn't realized being dressed in full costume that she was supposed to pay attention.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So those of us on the boat yelled, Gloria, G-L-O-R-I-A Claus, and that got her attention, then she realized she was supposed to throw candy to the kids.
That is quite a tale.
And from this point on, for the past five years, anytime ""Gloria"" is played in the bar, we always yelled Claus after G-L-O-R-I-A.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, now, I shall never think of it in the same way.
I will always have that little Claus in my brain.
